#Text=Sprint Nextel customer service rep . harasses client ; Sprint cancels his account
#Text=Sunday , July 22 , 2007

#Text=Virginia - Joshua Brady , a former Sprint Nextel customer , has had his cellular phone account shut off , but not because he was n't paying the phone bill , or even because he was late on payments , but because a customer service representative who assisted him , began to call him outside of her job , and make death threats to him in September of 2006 .
#Text=She was never fired for her actions , Brady says .
#Text=Brady has agreed to be interviewed by Wikinews to tell his story .
#Text=All information and claims have been logged with Brady 's attorney and federal authorities .

#Text=The representative from Sprint Nextel , who for safety reasons is only being identified as Jessica , was working at the company 's call center in Ontario , Canada where Brady 's call to customer service was directed .
#Text=According to Brady , Jessica then began to call him outside of her job duties at the call center after their first contact .
#Text=Brady called the center around 6:00 p.m. ( eastern time ) on a Saturday and attempted to receive help on a billing question and to find a way to stop prank calls .
#Text=Brady requested a " soc code " , a code placed into the phone , that would allow for the number that was pranking him to be blocked .

column1: #Text=Unfortunately , Jessica did not know what that was , but tried unsuccessfully to find it .
#Text=According to Brady , the only thing she could find was " the ANI feature call centers have .

#Text=He was being charged  for text messages I was not making " , even though he had unlimited text messaging with his billing plan .

column1: #Text=Meanwhile , Jessica called for a supervisor to help locate the code .

#Text=As this customer service request over the phone was taking quite a bit of time , the two of them then started to discuss what two people would normally discuss if just chatting ; sports , the weather , movies and music and if Virginia was a nice place to go on vacation .
#Text=The supervisor then came by Jessica 's station with no luck on finding a code .
#Text=Later that night , around 10:30 p. m. , Brady received a call .
#Text=He answered it and much to his surprise , it was Jessica .
#Text=He answered the phone with the usual " hello " and the voice on the other end answered with " hello Josh .

#Text=Brady said that he  immediately started to record " the call .

column1: #Text=Brady also stated that Jessica was not aware she was being recorded , and that further conversations were recorded without her knowing .
#Text=The call lasted about 15 minutes , but Brady said she " spoke so fast and moved along through things " that he " did n't have a chance to talk if I wanted to .

#Text=The advice he received was to  play along " and continue to report her actions until they could locate someone " better equipped " to handle the situation .

column1: #Text=Jessica then began to call " about every other day or so " which turned out to be almost 30 calls , according to Brady who reported each call she made to Sprint Nextel .
#Text=Sprint Nextel then told Jessica to cease and desist all contact with Brady , but that did n't stop Jessica from contacting him .
#Text=She somehow found out the screen-name of his AOL Instant Messenger account , and left messages threatening to kill him .
#Text=Brady logged the messages and faxed them to Sprint , who about a week later sent Brady a letter , saying that his accounts have been terminated .

#Text= While we have worked to resolve your issues and questions to the best of our ability , the number of inquiries you have made to us during this time had led us to determine that we are unable to meet your current wireless needs , " said one letter to a sprint customer as recent as June 29 , 2007 .

column1: #Text=The letter states that the service will be terminated just one day after the letter was written despite saying they " understand switching to a new carrier causes an inconvenience .

column3:

#Text= These accounts have been researched very carefully , " Sprint spokeswoman Roni Singleton said .

#Text= If the average person is calling less than once per month and these people are calling 40 or 50 times more , that takes away from customer service , " Singleton said .

column1: #Text=" Our priority is to improve the customer experience .
